Question 1: On watching the documentary 'The Secret of Our Lives: The Human Genome Project', a 
student reads up about the international consortium of scientists who fully deciphered the 
DNA of the most common chromosomal syndrome. What is this syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Trisomy 21 (Down’s syndrome) is the most common chromosomal syndrome. It is the second 
human chromosome whose DNA has been fully deciphered by the Human Genome Project. Chromosomal disorders: These may involve autosomal or sex chromosomes. Note: • Most common trisomy leading to miscarriage/incompatibility with life: Trisomy 16. • F body: Y chromosome (quinacrine, a fluorescence dye, binds strongly to the Y chromosome 
forming a bright fluorescent spot called an F body). Involving autosomes

questions.question:
Question 2: A 39-year-old pregnant woman was found to have an abnormal nuchal translucency scan. An 
amniocentesis done revealed a chromosomal karyotype of 47, XX,+21. This result most 
commonly occurs due to?
questions.explanation:
The chromosomal karyotype of 47, XX,+21 is suggestive of Down’s syndrome which occurs due to 
nondisjunction in maternal meiosis. Non-disjunction points to the failure of the homologous 
chromosome to separate during the meiotic division. Down’s syndrome: • Most common chromosomal disorder • Incidence: 1/800 live births • Mechanism: • Trisomy 21 (meiotic maternal nondisjunction) (95%) • Robertsonian translocation: 4% • Mosaic pattern: 1% Note: • Robertsonian translocations: involve 2 acrocentric chromosomes (chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, 
and 22) that fuse near the centromeric region, with a subsequent loss of the short arms.

questions.question:
Question 3: Your aunt has sent you an image of her 1-year-old son's palm using an instant messaging app. 
She read online that it is mostly present in genetic disorders and wishes to get your opinion. 
You identify it as a simian crease and prepare a list of differentials. All of the following 
diagnoses are correct except: 213 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Simian crease (single transverse palmar crease) is not seen in cystic fibrosis. Simian crease is seen in the following disorders: • Down's syndrome • Fetal alcohol syndrome 224 
Sold by @itachibot • Trisomy 13 • Cri du chat syndrome

questions.question:
Question 4: A girl is born at term after an uneventful pregnancy and delivery. On examination, she is 
noted to be hypotonic, has a protruding tongue, low set ears, an upward slant to the eyes with 
epicanthal folds, and a single palmar crease. On cardiac evaluation, what is the most common 
lesion expected in this syndrome?
questions.explanation:
The girl is suffering from Down’s syndrome and the most common cardiovascular lesion is 
an endocardial cushion defect. Other associated defects are atrial septum defects (ASD), ventricular septum defect (VSD), patent 
ductus arteriosus (PDA), aberrant subclavian artery, and pulmonary hypertension. Clinical features: (Mnemonic: I C A PROBLEM Somewhere) • Intellectual disability/Incurved or short fifth finger with clinodactyly • Congenital heart disease • Acute megakaryoblastic leukaemia/Alzheimer's disease/Atlantoaxial instability/Atresia of the 
duodenum • Protruding tongue • Round face • Occiput flat/Open wide fontanelle/Open mouth • Brachycephalic/Brushfield's spots • Low (depressed) nasal bridge • Epicanthal fold/Ears low set and dysplastic • Mongoloid slant (oblique palpebral fissure) • Simian palmar crease and wider gap between first and second toes Note: • The most common cause of intestinal obstruction in Down syndrome is duodenal 
atresia (double-bubble sign). • Children with Down's syndrome have an increased risk of developing leukaemias, including 
acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (ALL) and acute myeloid leukaemia (AML). • AML is more common during the first 3 years of life. • The most common AML associated with Down Syndrome is acute megakaryoblastic leukemia. • The most common haematological manifestation in Downs syndrome is transient abnormal 
myelopoiesis (TAM). • Brushfield's spots are whitish speckling on iris seen in light-skinned people. Image: A child having features of Down’s syndrome 225 
Sold by @itachibot Image: Brushfield's spots

questions.question:
Question 5: A 41-year-old entrepreneur is excited to start her family. She has been getting a lot of 
unsolicited advice about the complications of pregnancy in advanced maternal age. On 
enquiring about such pregnancies, the doctor advised the mother to get prenatal testing done. 
All are findings associated with the prenatal diagnosis for Down’s syndrome except 214 
Sold by @itachibot

options.d: Ventricular septal defect may be present

questions.explanation:
Increased umbilical flow is not seen during the prenatal screening for Down’s syndrome, instead, 
the flow is decreased. Reduced blood flow through the umbilical vessels and abnormal blood flow through ductus 
venosus (DV) in the first trimester are associated with chromosomal abnormalities, especially 
Down's syndrome. This decrease in blood flow causes IUGR in infants born with Down syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 7: While writing your medical competitive exams, you come across the following image of 
karyotyping analysis in a question. You recognize this image as being highly suggestive of a 
particular syndrome. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above karyotype is suggestive of Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13). Clinical features of Trisomy 13/Patau syndrome (Mnemonic CMC DOCToR OPD) • Cardiac defects (ventricular septal defect/atrial septal defect/patent ductus arteriosus) • Microcephaly, Microphthalmia • Cleft lip/palate • Developmental delay • Ocular hypotelorism • Holoprosencephaly • Thin posterior ribs (missing ribs) • Renal abnormalities • Polydactyly with flexed fingers • Polycystic kidneys • Scalp defects (aplasia cutis) Image: 37-week male with Patau syndrome demonstrating alobar holoprosencephaly with 
cyclopia. Facial features included a sloping forehead with a nose superior to a single central 
palpebral fissure. 227 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A 10-month-old boy presented with facial dysmorphism as well as two characteristic findings 
shown in the picture below. What is the condition affecting this newborn?
questions.explanation:
The newborn with features of facial dysmorphism, index finger overlapping other fingers, and 
rocker bottom feet are suggestive of Edward’s syndrome (Trisomy 18). Clinical features of Edward’s syndrome: (Remember mnemonic: Hi Mr EDWARDS) • Hypertonia • Microcephaly/Micrognathia • Eighteen trisomy/Elongated skull • Digit overlapping with a closed fist • Webbing of 2nd and 3rd toes • Absent intellect (severe developmental delay)/Absent radii/ Arthrogryposis • Rocker bottom feet • Cardiac Disorders (ventricular septal defect, patent ductus arteriosus, atrial septal defect) and 
kidney, death. • Small lower jaw (Micrognathia), short sternum, small nipples Note: P, Patau syndrome: Trisomy 13 E, Edward's syndrome: Trisomy 18 D, Down syndrome: Trisomy 21 Alagille syndrome (AS) is an autosomal-dominant disorder associated with abnormalities of the 
liver (hypoplasia of hepatic duct), heart (tetralogy of Fallot), skeleton, eye, and kidneys and a 
characteristic facial appearance. William's syndrome is a developmental disorder that is characterized by mild to moderate 
intellectual disability or learning problems, unique personality characteristics, distinctive facial 228 
Sold by @itachibot features, and cardiovascular problems.

questions.question:
Question 9: A young girl presents to you with learning disabilities. On examination, you notice a 
characteristic finding as shown in the picture below. Reports of her investigation scans 
mention horseshoe kidneys and streak gonads. What is your diagnosis? 216 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The child shows characteristic webbed neck, learning disabilities, horseshoe kidneys, and streak 
gonads and is diagnosed with Turner’s syndrome. Turner’s syndrome: • Karyotype, 45; XO, phenotypically females • Chromosomal abnormality XO is present in 60% of individuals, mosaic pattern in 40% • Intelligence remains normal Important features associated with Turner's syndrome: (mnemonic: See A Baby CLOWN Here) • Short stature, Short fourth metacarpal, Sensorineural hearing loss, Shield chest • Amenorrhea (primary), infertility • Barr body absent • Cardiac defects, Cubitus valgus, Congenital lymphedema • L: Learning disabilities • Ovaries underdeveloped (streak ovaries), Gonadoblastoma (increased risk if Y chromosome 
material is present) • Webbed neck • Nipples widely spaced • Horseshoe kidneys Note: The most common cardiac defect in Turner's is bicuspid aortic valve > coarctation of aorta.

questions.question:
Question 10: Kaveri recently became pregnant following a history of repeated abortions. She was anxious 
and wanted to undergo karyotyping this time to detect chromosomal disorders pre-natally. 
Barr body was found to be absent in her report. Which of the following is associated with an 
absent Barr body?
questions.explanation:
Barr body is absent in female having 45 X0 genome. Barr body • Densely staining inactivated condensed X chromosome present in each somatic cell of a female 
is found in the nucleus. • Chromatid body (Barr body or sex chromatin) is derived from one of the two X chromosomes 
which become inactivated. • The number of Barr bodies is thus one less than the number of X chromosomes. Turner's syndrome is female without Barr body. Klinefelter's syndrome is male with Barr body. 229 
Sold by @itachibot Note: • Lyon hypothesis states that only one of the two X chromosomes in a female is functional, the 
other becomes inactive during embryogenesis. • Davidson bodies are small nuclear buds of chromatin shaped like a drumstick found in 
neutrophils of females.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 15-year-old adolescent presents with an anti-mongoloid slant, pulmonary stenosis, short 
stature, webbed neck, and undescended testis. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The adolescent presenting with antimongoloid slant, pulmonary stenosis, short stature, webbed 
neck, and undescended testis is suggestive of Noonan syndrome. Although the webbed neck is a 
feature of Turner syndrome as well, the likely diagnosis would be Noonan syndrome since the 
patient is male (undescended testis). Noonan syndrome: • Autosomal-dominant disorder (12q) • Male or female with Turner phenotype; normal karyotype. Clinical features: • Down-slanting palpebral fissure (antimongoloid slant) • Pectus carinatum • Hypertelorism • Cryptorchidism • Low levels of clotting factor 11 and 12 • Leukemia (Juvenile chronic myelogenous leukemia) • Moderate mental retardation in 25% • Cardiac abnormality: Most common is pulmonary valve stenosis. • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy • Atrial Septal Defect • Coarctation of aorta • Short stature, webbed neck, low set ears, cubitus valgus: similarities with Turner syndrome • Ptosis, micrognathia, clinodactyly, delayed puberty. questions.question:
Question 12: A concerned pregnant woman underwent karyotyping which was highly suggestive of a 
particular syndrome. The image of her results is shown below. Which of the following 
abnormalities is associated with patients with the given karyotype?
questions.explanation:
The above karyotype - 47, XXY, is suggestive of Klinefelter’s syndrome, in which gynecomastia 
and long thin limbs are seen. Klinefelter’s syndrome: • Most common sex aneuploidy in males • Classically karyotype is 47, XXY. Other variants can have 48 XXXY; rarely, 49 XXXXY; or 
mosaics with some cells containing normal 46, XY and others 47, XXY • Results from meiotic nondisjunction of sex chromosomes (mostly during 1st meiotic division) Clinical features: • Disproportionately long arms and legs • Mitral valve prolapse • Mental retardation; IQ: 60-80 • Minor developmental and learning disabilities • Lack of secondary sexual characteristics (due to a decrease in androgen production) • Gynecomastia • Higher risk of breast carcinoma • Testicular dysgenesis 231 
Sold by @itachibot • Infertility/ azoospermia Note: A variant of Klinefelter’s syndrome—49, XXXXY—presents with short stature.

questions.question:
Question 13: A newborn with previously diagnosed Cri-du-chat syndrome presented to the hospital. Which 
of the following is not observed in this condition?
questions.explanation: Hypotonia is seen in cri-du-chat syndrome, not hypertonia. Cri-du-chat syndrome occurs due to the deletion of chromosome 5p. Main features: • • Hypotonia • Characteristic shrill cry (cat-like cry) in the first few weeks of life • Microcephaly • Hypertelorism • Bilateral epicanthic folds • High-arched palate • Wide and flat nasal bridge • Intellectual disability Note: • Cat-bite infection is caused by Pasteurella multocida. • Tomcat urine odor is seen in multiple carboxylase deficiencies.

Question 14: 218 
Sold by @itachibot A senior asks you to read about an autosomal dominant condition known as Treacher- Collins 
syndrome. While browsing through numerous journals to learn about the topic, you come 
across a doubt about its features. Which of the following is not associated with this 
syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Intelligence is not affected in Treacher–Collins syndrome (like in Turners syndrome). Treacher– Collins syndrome/Franceschetti syndrome • Autosomal dominant • Facial appearance: downward sloping palpebral fissures, colobomas and drooping of the lower 
eyelids, sunken cheekbones, deformed pinnae, atypical hair growth extending towards cheeks • Facial clefts, malformed ears, deafness • Hypoplastic mandible Image: Treacher–Collins syndrome; note the sunken cheekbones, abnormality of ears, and 
hypoplastic mandible 232 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: All of the following are seen in a 5-month-old child with Pierre- Robin syndrome except?
questions.explanation:
Coloboma iris is not a feature of Pierre–Robin syndrome. Features of Pierre–Robin syndrome- • Micrognathia accompanied by a high-arched or cleft palate • Tongue normal size; the floor of the mouth is foreshortened • Retrognathia: retracted mandible • Glossoptosis/Retroglossoptosis: tongue appears to fall into the throat (retraction of the tongue) Of the children with Pierre–Robin syndrome, 30–50% have Stickler syndrome. Features 
include prominent joints, arthritis, hypotonia, hypermobile joints, mitral valve prolapse, hearing 
loss, and ocular problems (myopia, glaucoma, cataracts, retinal detachment). Pierre–Robin syndrome as shown in the image below: 233 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: Shantanu, an avid reader, and a first-year resident, recently finished Joseph Heller's famous 
novel 'Catch-22'. While discussing the book with his friend, he realized that the title was an 
acronym of a chromosomal disorder they had studied. Which of the following is the least 
likely feature of this disorder?
questions.explanation:
DiGeorge syndrome, also known as Catch-22 syndrome, is associated with cardiac anomalies and 
not cranial anomalies. DiGeorge/Shprintzen Velocardiofacial syndrome - Remember the mnemonic CATCH 22 • C: Cardiac anomalies • A: Abnormal facies • T: Thymic aplasia and agenesis of parathyroid glands. • C: Cleft palate • H: Hypocalcemia, hypoplasia of auricle • 22: 22q11.2 deletion

questions.question:
Question 17: Riya was found to have a height of more than 95 percentile for her age and an arm-span to 
height ratio of more than 1.05. On further examination, she had flat feet, mild scoliosis, and 
long slender fingers. An image of her hands showing two characteristic signs is provided 
below. What other complications can be expected in this child? 219 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given features are suggestive of a diagnosis of Marfan's syndrome. Subluxation of the lens is a 
known complication. Image (a) shows Walker-Murdoch (wrist) sign - the ability to join the thumb and fifth finger 
around the wrist. Image (b) shows Steinberg (thumb) sign - thumb tip extends from the palm of the hand in a closed 
fist Features of Marfan's syndrome (Mnemonic: MARFAN’S) • Mitral valve prolapse • Myopia due to upward dislocation of the lens (bilateral ectopic lentis) 234 
Sold by @itachibot • Aortic root dilatation, Aortic regurgitation • Retinal detachment • Fibrillin 1 gene defect: Reduced fibrillin 1 production causing joint laxity • Fifteen (Chromosome 15 is involved) • Flat feet • Arachnodactyly, Astigmatism, Air in lungs (Pneumothorax) • Nearsightedness • Subluxation of lens, Scoliosis, Speech disorders, Sleep apnea The image given below shows the Steinberg (thumb) sign:

questions.question: Question 19: Triangular facies is indicative of which of the following diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Triangular facies is indicative of Russell–Silver syndrome. Russell–Silver syndrome: • Clinical features: Short stature, triangular face (small jaw and pointed chin), microcephaly, limb 
and facial asymmetry, 5th finger clinodactyly. • A few cases are due to genomic imprinting disorder involving chromosome 11. Note: Triangular facies is also seen in Alagille syndrome. The image given below shows a child with Russell–Silver syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 20: During an intersectoral collaborative event, an award-winning geneticist from the National 
Human Genome Research Institute is invited for an endowment oration. He presents his 
lecture on an experimental form of treatment that uses the transfer of genetic material to cure 
diseases known as 'Gene Therapy'. Which of the following techniques does he mention for 
this therapy?
questions.explanation:
Electroporation is used in gene therapy. Gene therapy is a technique that uses genes to treat or prevent disease through the delivery of 
DNA into a patient's cell by using recombinant viruses/naked DNA/DNA complexes. The methods 236 
Sold by @itachibot used include intranuclear injection, electroporation, gene-gun, sonoporation, and magnetofection. Gene therapy was first used for severe combined immunodeficiency disorder (SCID), which is due 
to adenosine deaminase enzyme deficiency.

questions.question:
Question 21: The following is the finding noted in a 12-month-old baby who is growing well and developing 
normally since birth. Which of the following is a true statement regarding this finding? 221 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy should be suspected
options.d: Chromosomal analysis should be done to rule out other chromosomal abnormalities

questions.explanation:
The picture depicts a Simian crease – a single transverse palmar crease. It is a normal finding 
in about 3% of the population. In a child with simian crease and normal growth and 
development, reassurance should be provided. • A simian crease is one of the findings of Down's syndrome however presence of only this finding 
should not lead to a diagnosis of Down's syndrome. • Maternal history of phenytoin intake during pregnancy does not lead to this finding. However, 
maternal alcohol intake can be associated with this condition. • Chromosomal analysis in an otherwise well child is not indicated.

questions.question:
Question 22: Non-invasive prenatal screening (NIPS) is particularly useful in the modern era of diagnosis 
in clinical genetics. Which of the following statements is not true regarding this test?
questions.explanation:
Non-invasive prenatal screening (NIPS) has a high negative predictive value. NIPS: • Useful in screening high-risk pregnancies for aneuploidies. • Done after 10 weeks of gestation. • Evaluates maternal blood for screening. • Positive tests need confirmation by invasive testing (like amniocentesis, chorionic villous 
sampling). 237 
Sold by @itachibot Metabolic Disorders of Amino Acids
